name: Ceylon Python
description: It is a robust snake with a creamy belly, irregular spots on its sides and back, and a distinctive arrow-shaped pattern on its triangular head. Compared to the nominate subspecies, it tends to have more contrasting colors and a more vividly colored head, though it is lighter than the dark Burmese python (P. m. bivittatus).
image_alt: Ceylon Python, photo: Prague Zoo Archive
proportions: Length 2.5–3.5 m, with about 20% being the tail; weight up to 40 kg
reproduction: Females lay up to 40 eggs; incubation at 30°C takes around 60 days
attractions: It is one of the subspecies of the well-known Indian python. Though sometimes not recognized as a distinct subspecies and considered a smaller form of the mainland Indian python (P. m. molurus), recent studies confirm it as a separate subspecies. It primarily stays on the ground but is an excellent swimmer and adept at climbing trees.
breeding: The first Indian python was donated to the zoo by a breeders' association in 1939. We have kept the Ceylon python since 1992.
